During bacterial cell division, the tubulin-homolog FtsZ 17 polymerizes into treadmilling filaments that further assemble into a cytoskeletal ring. 18 Although minimal in vitro assays have shown the striking self-organization capacity of 19 FtsZ filaments, such as dynamic chiral assemblies, how these large-scale structures 20 emerge and relate to individual filament properties remains poorly understood. To 21 understand this quantitatively, we combined minimal chiral active matter simulations 22 with biochemical reconstitution experiments. Using STED and TIRF microscopy as well 23 as high-speed AFM, we imaged the behavior of FtsZ filaments on different spatial scales. 24 Simulations and experiments revealed that filament density and flexibility define the 25 local and global order of the system: At intermediate densities, flexible filaments organize 26 into chiral rings and polar bands, while an effectively nematic organization dominates for 27 high filament densities and for mutant filaments with increased rigidity. Our predicted 28 phase diagram captured these features quantitatively, demonstrating how filament 29 flexibility, density and chirality cooperate with activity to give rise to a large repertoire 30 of collective behaviors. These properties are likely important for the dynamic 31 organization of soft chiral matter, including that of treadmilling FtsZ filaments during 32 bacterial cell division. 33

34 Introduction 35 In active systems, the emergence of large-scale order relies on a combination of local 36 interactions between components and microscopic energy consumption. One typical 37 property of such self-organizing systems is spontaneous motility of their constituents. 38 For example, cytoskeletal filaments can be transported due to the activity of motor 39 proteins or move due to treadmilling polymerization dynamics. Dynamic interactions 40 between active constituents can lead to complex collective behavior and phases not found 41 at equilibrium, which have been under intense experimental and theoretical 42 investigation in the past decade1–7. Reconstituted mixtures of actin or microtubule 43 filaments with motor proteins self-organize into moving swarms, vortices, and travelling 44 waves1,5,8. In living systems, such emergent behaviors can underlie a wealth of key 45 biological phenomena such as single and collective cell motility9,10, cell division11 and 46 organism morphogenesis12,13. 47 Active matter systems can be classified according to the symmetry of its 48 constituents (e.g. polar or nematic)14–16. In particular, chiral active matter has recently 49 attracted attention, where the constituents are either asymmetric in shape or perform a 50 circular self-propelled motion. This includes curved cytoskeletal filaments, asymmetric 51 synthetic swimmers or cell types displaying chiral motions on 2D substrates17–19. 52 However, how to relate the microscopic properties of active constituents to the large-53 scale outputs relevant for biology remains an outstanding challenge in the field16. For 54 instance, biological settings often involve highly dense systems with attraction, as well as 55 deformable constituents which can change their shape as a function of external forces or 56 crowding6. How flexible constituents self-organize and how their local deformability 57 contributes to large-scale collective features remain poorly understood, both 58 theoretically and experimentally. 59 One example of treadmilling filaments are polymers formed by the protein FtsZ, a 60 tubulin homolog that organizes cell division in almost all bacterial, and some archaeal, 61 species20,21. FtsZ forms single stranded filaments that grow from one end and shrink from 62 the opposite end22, driven by the hydrolysis of guanosine triphosphate (GTP). FtsZ 63 filaments can also interact laterally, which facilitates the condensation of filaments from 64 a diffuse organization into a tight ring-like structure called the Z-ring23–26. FtsZ also 66 forms treadmilling filaments in vitro, which organize into cytoskeletal patterns of moving 67 bands and chirally rotating rings28. While lateral interactions between treadmilling 68 filaments play an important role for Z-ring assembly in living cells and the emergence of 69 cytoskeletal structures in vitro, the physical properties and interaction rules of 70 treadmilling filaments on a membrane surface are currently not well known. Here, by 71 studying the self-organization of FtsZ filaments at different spatial and temporal scales, 72 we elucidate the quantitative principles that govern the emergence of different collective 73 cytoskeletal organizations from the local interactions of active constituents. 74 75 Modes of FtsZ filaments self-organization at different densities 76 To understand the properties of FtsZ filament bundling, we first explored experimentally 77 the phase space of possible organizations of FtsZ filaments as a function of their density. 78 We used a previously established in vitro reconstitution assay, where treadmilling FtsZ 79 filaments are recruited to the surface of a supported bilayer by the membrane anchor 80 FtsA28. Using total internal reflection fluorescence (TIRF) microscopy, we could record 81 the emergent behavior of the membrane-bound filaments. We found that we could 82 control the density of membrane-bound FtsZ filaments by changing the FtsZ 83 concentration in the buffer solution. When we increased the FtsZ bulk concentration from 84 around 0.6 to 5 µM while keeping the FtsA concentration constant, the fluorescence 85 intensity of FtsZ on the membrane increased linearly until it saturated at concentrations 86 higher than 3 µM (Supplementary Fig. 1a). At the same time, we found that the large-87 scale organization of the filaments changed with their density (Fig. 1a, Supplementary 88 Movie 1). 89 At FtsZ concentrations lower than 0.6 µM, individual filaments traveled across the 90 membrane surface28. These filaments were too short to measure their intrinsic curvature 91 by fluorescence microscopy, but maximum intensity projections of time lapse movies 92 revealed that their trajectories followed a curved path corresponding to a circle with a 93 diameter of 1.16 µm ± 0.35 µm and heavily biased in the clockwise direction (Fig. 1b, 94 Supplementary Fig. 1b). 95 When we increased the FtsZ bulk concentrations to 1.25 and 1.5 µM, FtsZ 96 filaments organized into chiral rotating rings that persisted for around 5-6 min and 97 coexisted with comet-like structures and moving bundles of treadmilling filaments as 98

When we calculated the directional autocorrelation of 99 cytoskeletal flows, we found a long decay time of 16 and 68 seconds at 1.25 and 1.5 µM 100 FtsZ respectively, consistent with persistent, long-range polar motion of filament 101 bundles. In fluorescence recovery after photobleaching experiments we found that the 102 mean lifetime of FtsZ monomers in filament bundles was only around 7 s, suggesting that 103 their directional motion is a collective property of the system (Fig. 1c, Supplementary 104 Fig. 1c). 105 At bulk concentrations of 3 µM and higher, filaments densely covered the 106 membrane surface without apparent large-scale organization or directional movements. 107 FtsZ filaments still continuously exchanged monomers at these high densities, with a 108 recovery half-time of around 15s (Supplementary Fig. 1d). 109 These features were also recapitulated using time-lapse stimulated emission depletion 110 (STED) microscopy. Compared to TIRF microscopy, STED provided higher resolution but 111 did not allow for long-term imaging of the filament pattern. It still showed that rings form 112 preferentially at intermediate densities, and are comprised of many transiently 113 interacting FtsZ filaments (Fig. 1d, Supplementary Movie 2, Supplementary Fig. 1e). 114 The apparent weak interactions between filaments suggest that their local polar 115 orientation is an emergent property of the ensemble, rather than the result of highly 116 specific static interactions, such as residue contacts between individual filaments 117 (Supplementary Fig. 1f, g). 118 Together, these observations and quantifications show that there are density-119 dependent transitions of the large-scale organization and motion of treadmilling 120 filaments. 121 122 Collective filament organization as a function of bending rigidity and attraction. 123 Given our experimental findings that single FtsZ filaments displace along curved, chiral 124 paths, and previous theoretical work showing that non-adhesive chiral self-propelled 125 filaments could organize into ring-like phases at intermediate densities2, we explored 126 whether a minimal coarse-grained model could quantitatively reproduce the observed 127 phenomenology. At the other extreme, filaments with 154 very low bending rigidity deformed too easily and formed only rare and unstable chiral 155 rings at all density tested. Together, this phase diagram argues that filament flexibility 156 could be a key parameter for FtsZ self-organization. 157 More quantitatively, by analyzing the average filament curvature in our 158 simulations, we found that the nature of self-organization in high densities was markedly 159 different with varying filament flexibility (Fig. 2b, d). In the case of very rigid filaments, 160 even above the critical density where well-defined rings disappeared in simulations, we 161 found that individual filaments were still highly curved and could self-organize into spiral 162 patterns. For low attraction, we systematically observed a transition from 170 disordered patterns to rings above a critical density, as previously reported2. 171 Interestingly however, for strong FtsZ attraction, this transition was largely lost, with 172 rings able to form even at the lowest experimental densities (Supplementary Fig. 2c, 173 3a), similarly to the case of very rigid filaments. From a physical perspective, this is due 174 to ring formation being energetically favored, instead of being an active kinetic state in 175 the case of purely repulsive self-propelled filaments. The Peclet number also strongly 176 affected the first transition, as well as the overall density of rings in the system 177 (Supplementary Fig. 2d, 3b). Above a second threshold of density, we could observe in 178 all cases a loss of ring patterns. 179 180 Quantitative comparison between model and experiments. 181 To more systematically and quantitatively compare simulations and experiments, 182 we first sought to constrain model parameters. From our observations of single-filament 183 trajectories (Fig. 1b) and previously published values28,35 we considered a treadmilling 184 speed of v0 = 0.04 5m/s, and estimated the packing fraction of filaments 6 based on our 185 calibration experiments (Supplementary Fig. 1a). The aspect ratio of filaments in our 186 mesoscopic simulations corresponded to bundles with thickness of 5 FtsZ filaments of 187 length 400 nm (see section Material & Methods for more details on parameter 188 estimation). Estimation of filament chirality based on curvature of single-filament 189 trajectories was noisy and limited by the resolution of fluorescence microscopy, but still 190 allowed us to guide parameter space by estimating /0 to yield the single-filament rotation 191 diameter of 500-1000 nm, as well as a lower bound for the Peclet number of ~100 192 (Supplementary Fig. 3k). Therefore, after this parameter estimation, we were left with 193 only three fitting parameters, which we systematically explored in our simulations: the 194 adhesion strength 7 , the filament flexibility measured by flexure number ℱ and noise 195 strength measured by Peclet number Pe. 196

Interestingly, intermediate values of filament flexibility, as well as low to 197 intermediate attraction, provided a good match for a number of qualitative and 198 quantitative features of our dataset. Firstly, we could quantitatively reproduce not only 199 the two thresholds of appearance and disappearance of rings as a function of density, but 200 also the absolute probability of ring formation in the intermediary density region (Fig. 201 2g). Strikingly, when measuring ring life-time (normalized by period of filament rotation) 202 in both experiments and simulations, we found excellent agreement with our predicted 203 parameter regime (Fig. 2h, Supplementary Fig. 3c, d). Finally, our simulations 204 predicted that the diameter and thickness of rings should monotonously increase with 205 density, a feature in agreement with the data (Fig. 2i, Supplementary Fig. 3e, f). Overall, 206 this demonstrates that the transitions seen in the data as a function of density can be 207 quantitatively explained by a simple theoretical framework of flexible chiral active 208 filaments. Interestingly, this analysis suggests FtsZ filaments being much more flexible 209 than previously anticipated2,30 . This prompted us to test more directly how FtsZ filament 210 conformation changes at the microscopic level as a function of increasing density. 211 212 High-speed-AFM imaging of dynamic FtsZ filaments 213 As fluorescence microscopy was not sufficient to visualize individual filaments inside of 214 dense filament bundles, we applied high speed atomic force microscopy (HS-AFM) on 215 treadmilling, membrane-bound filaments, which allowed temporal imaging of biological 216 samples at high lateral resolution down to 2-3 nm and at up to 20 frames per second36,37. 217 We were able to image individual filaments that dynamically moved across the 218 membrane surface and increased in density during the course of the experiments. These 219 filaments rapidly moved in and out of the field of view, which made it difficult to track 220 individual filaments over time. However, these time-lapse movies confirmed that 221 neighboring filaments did not form stable lateral contacts; instead they displayed fast 222 lateral fluctuations on the membrane surface (Fig. 3 a, Supplementary Movie 6). This 223 suggests that the attraction energy was comparable or smaller to fluctuations, consistent 224 with our numerical simulations. We could also reconstruct filament shape as a function 225 of density. Interestingly, we found a gradual decrease in filament curvature as a function 226 of overall surface density, which fitted well our theoretical prediction for semiflexible 227 filaments (Fig. 3b). At the highest densities, filaments had no discernable intrinsic 228 curvature and showed hallmarks of active nematics, such as spontaneous formation of 229

This confirms that their organization at high densities is governed 231 by nematic rather than polar filament-filament interactions. 232 233 Testing the model by changing filament conformation 234 Since our theory suggests that semiflexible filaments and intrinsic chirality are crucial to 235 explain the density-dependent transitions that we observed experimentally, we sought 236 to challenge it further by using constituents with altered properties, i.e. straight filaments 237 with enhanced bending rigidity. We reviewed previously described FtsZ mutants and 238 identified FtsZ L169R as an interesting candidate protein. This mutant was previously 239 described to have increased lateral interactions, as it shows enhanced bundling in vitro 240 and in vivo38,39. We used Alphafold40,41 predictions of a FtsZ-FtsZ dimer using the crystal 241 structure of FtsZ filaments from Staphylococcus aureus as a template42 and found that the 242 positively charged Arginine residue at position 169 is in fact located at the longitudinal 243 interface, facing towards a negatively charged Glutamic acid residue at position 276 of 244 the neighboring monomer (Fig. 4a). Accordingly, the L169R mutation could result in an 245 additional salt-bridge between two monomers in the filament, which could straighten 246 and stiffen the resulting filaments. Indeed, our HS-AFM experiments with this FtsZ 247 mutant confirmed our hypothesis and also revealed a number of key differences from the 248 wildtype protein. First, while wildtype filaments moved in and out of the field of view, 249 filaments of FtsZ L169R mutant protein appeared to be more static. This loss of mobility 250 suggests that their kinetic polarity is perturbed (Supplementary Movie 7). We indeed 251 found that many filaments displayed bidirectional growth and sudden shrinkage events 252 rather than treadmilling behavior. Second, our HS-AFM experiments showed that single 253 filaments appeared to have lower intrinsic curvature and less fluctuations than filaments 254 of the wildtype protein even at very low densities (Fig. 4b). When we analyzed the shape 255 of individual filaments at different densities, we found that the curvature of wildtype 256 filaments decreased two-fold with increasing density, while mutant filaments were 257 almost straight at all densities studied (Fig. 4c). At the same time the persistence and 258 contour lengths were about two times higher for FtsZ L169R filaments and further 259 increased with their densities (Fig. 4d, e). We also found that mutant filaments showed 260 transient filament interactions and height profile similar to the wildtype filaments, but 261 with a two times smaller mean filament distance (Supplementary Fig. 4a-c)38. 262

Given that we previously had assumed a local polar order between filaments in 263 our mesoscopic bundle simulations, we now wanted to test the effect of the filament 264 properties of FtsZ L169R. We thus quantified local filament-filament alignment in toy-265 simulations with different filament parameters. Interestingly, we found that all changes 266 observed in the FtsZ L169R mutant (longer, less chiral, or more persistent filaments with 267 slower treadmilling) went in the same direction of decreasing polar filament alignment 268 (Supplementary Fig. 4e-h). Combining these three experimentally observed static 269 properties thus predicted a strong decrease of local polarity sorting (Fig. 5a, b, 270 Supplementary Fig. 4d, Supplementary Movie 8). We then examined the experimental 271 large-scale patterns of mutant FtsZ filaments via TIRF microscopy. FtsZ L169R 272 polymerized into a cytoskeletal network of dynamic filament bundles at concentrations 273 between 0.6 µM and 3 µM (Fig. 5c, Supplementary Movie 9). We found that while the 274 mutant reached saturation on membranes with FtsA similarly to the wildtype, its 275 turnover was 2-3x slower and that it hydrolyzed GTP 3x slower compared to the wildtype 276 (Supplementary Fig. 4i-k). Furthermore, we did not observe any directional flows or 277 chirally rotating rings on the membrane surface. In addition, differential imaging did not 278 generate directional moving speckles, confirming that local polar arrangement of 279 filaments is strongly impaired (Supplementary Fig. 4l)35. These features were well-280 recapitulated by the same large-scale bundle simulations as before, but with the HS-AFM-281 derived properties for the mutant filaments: longer, less chiral and more persistent 282 filaments with slower kinetics Fp (Fig. 5d, Supplementary Movie 10). Altogether, this 283 shows that our simplified model can provide a powerful framework to link the local 284 microscopic structure of active filaments to the large-scale collective phases that they 285 form as a function of density. 286 287 Discussion 288 In this study, we have identified density-driven transitions in the self-organization of FtsZ 289 filaments between three phases: a low density disordered phase where individual 290 filaments treadmill in a chiral manner with little interactions, an intermediate density 291 phase where coherent chiral vortices form - as previously shown theoretically and 292 experimentally2,28,30 , and a high density phase where individual filaments straighten and 293 where the system displays a uniform, nematic-like organization. of active, chiral and flexible filaments we computationally analyzed how the physical 295 properties of self-propelled filaments determine their large-scale self-organization. 296 Although the presence of rings in intermediate densities can arise in the context of purely 297 repulsive rigid filaments, a key finding from our computational work is that varying 298 filament bending rigidity and attractive interactions changes qualitatively and 299 quantitatively the phase diagram of possible morphologies. We find that the 300 experimental system is consistent with intermediate values of both parameters, as 301 filament flexibility in particular significantly modifies ring statistics and lifetimes. With 302 semiflexible filaments, we observe indeed a competition between chiral shape, active 303 treadmilling and inter-filament interactions, which at intermediate densities results in 304 the co-existence and interconversion of chiral vortices and nematic-like traveling bands. 305 This recapitulates well our experimental observations made on different spatial scales: 306 while TIRF and STED microscopy allowed us to visualize the large-scale spatiotemporal 307 dynamics of FtsZ filaments - and thus the transitions between different phases - HS-AFM 308 revealed the behavior of individual filaments at different filament densities on a 309 membrane surface. This data confirmed that the transition from chiral vortices to a 310 nematic-like organization with increasing density goes along with straightening of the 311 filaments, arguing for a relatively low FtsZ bending rigidity. 312 Furthermore, we demonstrated that a local perturbation, in this case a specific 313 residue in the primary sequence of a protein, can dramatically change both individual 314 filament properties and collective self-organization. Specifically, we found that the 315 presence of an additional salt bridge between two monomers in filaments of FtsZ L169R 316 increases their rigidity and lowers their intrinsic curvature. As a consequence, this 317 mutant does not show a density dependent transition between different phases and 318 instead always displays achiral, non-directional large-scale cytoskeletal networks. FtsZ 319 L169R was originally described as bundling mutant that shows enhanced lateral 320 interactions38,39. Our data suggests that enhanced lateral interactions are a consequence 321 of mutant filaments being longer, more rigid and straighter and that the closer contact 322 between them is only a secondary effect. The lack of a preference for a polar orientation 323 of straight filaments are also in agreement with the observation of aberrant rings and 324 spiral structures of FtsZ L169R found in vivo38. Although the intrinsic curvature of 325 wildtype FtsZ filaments is much lower than that of MreB43 and FtsA filaments44, it could 326

contribute to the correct alignment of the Z-ring perpendicular to the long cell axis in 327 particular at early stages of cell division45. 328 Several experimental examples of chiral active matter have emerged in the past 329 few years, across many different length scales. At the organismal scale, malaria parasites 330 have been shown to have flexible rod-like shape and migrate actively in a chiral manner 331 with different parasites having opposite chirality. This leads to sorting based on chirality, 332 which is favored by mechanical flexibility46. Starfish embryos, although spherical in 333 shapes, have also recently been shown to swim in a chiral manner, and collectively form 334 crystal-like structures with odd elastic behavior47. At the cellular scale, chirality can bias 335 the active nematic instabilities observed in confluent monolayers 48 and biofilms49. This 336 has further been proposed to arise from cytoskeletal organization, due to the polar 337 helicoidal structure of active filaments50, highlighting the need to a better understanding 338 of the collective dynamics bridging different scales. In particular, it would be interesting 339 in the future to investigate more complex models of filament treadmilling, for instance 340 incorporating finite lifetimes or stress-dependent polymerization. Furthermore, our 341 experimental and theoretical data suggests that weak and transient lateral interactions 342 lacking any apparent biochemical specificity are sufficient for the alignment of 343 treadmilling filaments on a membrane surface. Indeed, in vivo filaments in the Z-ring can 344 move either in the same or opposite direction51,52 and recent experiments in Bacillus 345 subtilis suggest that filament treadmilling facilitates their encounters promoting 346 condensation of filaments into the Z-ring23. Relying on weak, non-specific interactions 347 instead of specific residue contacts is therefore likely advantageous for the cell as it 348 allows for the condensation of the Z-ring, while still permitting its dynamic 349 reorganization. The relatively low bending rigidity that we observe for FtsZ could also be 350 key to allow the Z-ring to adapt to the decreasing diameter of the constricting cell septum. 351 Overall, our study highlights how minimal models of active matter based on symmetries 352 can provide quantitative insights into fundamental biological functions. 353 354
